report_title: Industry Report on Fruit and Vegetable Markets
executive_summary: Companies in the fruit and vegetable markets industry tend to be minor, local vendors that sell fruit, vegetables, meat, dairy and various frozen products, which are predominantly sold to households and individuals. Industry revenue has risen at a CAGR of 4.3% over the five years to 2024 to reach an estimated $7.2 billion in 2024 when revenue is expected to increase by 7.7%. While per capita consumption of fruits and vegetables has declined during the same period, the prices of key products have climbed, facilitating industry growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Prices of Fruit and Vegetables Have Risen
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, the prices of fruit and vegetables have seen robust growth, driving revenue expansion due to factors such as drought conditions, supply chain disruptions, labor shortages and inflationary pressures.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Rise of Locally Sourced Produce
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers increasingly prioritize locally sourced fruits and vegetables, leading to thriving farmers' markets and community-supported agriculture (CSA) programs. Shoppers seek fresher, more nutritious options while aiming to reduce their carbon footprint by minimizing transportation distances.

The organic food movement is gaining momentum, with consumers ready to pay a premium for organic fruits and vegetables to avoid exposure to chemicals and additives. Sales of organic produce show double-digit growth annually, reflecting a significant shift in consumer preferences towards healthier and safer food options.

Busy lifestyles drive the popularity of pre-packaged and ready-to-eat fruit and vegetable options, providing time-saving solutions for consumers. Products like pre-cut fruits, salad kits and vegetable snacks are witnessing increased sales as they meet the need for convenience without sacrificing nutrition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers increasingly turn to organic fruits and vegetables out of concern for their health and the environment. There is a widespread belief that organic produce is healthier and free from harmful pesticides and chemicals that can affect human health and ecosystems.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technological Advancements in Agriculture Will Advance the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Precision farming uses GPS, IoT sensors and drones to collect data on crop health, soil conditions and weather. This data helps farmers make informed decisions, optimize resource use and increase yields.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Emphasis on Sustainability and Reducing Food Waste
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Both consumers and businesses are placing a greater emphasis on sustainability in food production and consumption. Shoppers are more likely to choose products from companies known for their environmentally friendly practices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rise of Local and Urban Farming
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Local sourcing and urban farming are gaining traction as methods to reduce the carbon footprint associated with food transportation. By growing produce closer to where it is consumed, these practices help cut down on greenhouse gas emissions.

industry_definition: Fruit and vegetable vendors sell a variety of produce, meats and other items through stands, farmers' markets and retail locations where products are sold directly to the public. The industry's permanent stands and markets are small and individually owned. This unique industry generates revenue from the sale of fruits and vegetables.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

opportunities: Demand from food and beverage stores

key_trends: The industry endures competition from supermarkets, grocery stores and convenience stores. These competitors often have access to larger supply chains.
Fruit and vegetable retailers operate on a local basis. No retailer will have the opportunity to compete on a national level.
Swelling fruit and vegetable prices have driven industry revenue growth over the past five years. This has been dampened by a slight drop in per capita fruit and vegetable consumption.

Consumers are increasingly choosing organic produce due to health and environmental concerns. To meet this rising demand, retailers are expanding their organic offerings and farmers are transitioning to organic methods despite the significant investment required.
There are no major companies in the industry. The largest players are groups of associated farmer's markets, typically in major cities.
In order to operate, fruit and vegetable retailers must comply with regulations. For example, these markets must obtain necessary permits and successfully pass mandatory inspections.
The industry operates with a low level of capital intensity, largely relying on manual labor. Hence, the major expenditure for this industry is predominantly on labor costs.

Profit for fruit and vegetable markets is expected to remain stable over the five years to 2024 because of their status as staple food items. Despite post-pandemic behavioral changes, home cooking trends benefit these markets, sustaining profit levels.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment accounts for fruit and vegetable consumption from consumers aged 18 and under. Children younger than four have one of the highest-quality diets, while adolescents aged 14 to 18 have the least healthy diet across all age groups.

Many consumers of this age group enter adulthood with an unhealthy diet established during adolescence. As a result, many people aged 19 to 30 shift their preferences toward healthier food options as they obtain a higher level of education and more money to spend, so the average consumption of fruits and vegetables by this group is higher compared with the group of 14 to 18 years old.
People in this age group tend to eat healthier food as they have a higher disposable income than younger groups and often want to serve as role models for their children and families.

This demographic is more focused on healthy eating because of potential dietary restrictions or focus on greater health consciousness. People of this age group consume more fruits than those aged 31 to 50 and nearly the same number of vegetables.

This demographic requires less calorie intake than those aged 51 to 70, resulting in a lower food consumption overall. However, this age group consistently holds a significant market for this industry and is expected to expand as the baby boomer population ages.

market_segmentation.segment: Retailers, wholesalers and distributors that resell products
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises businesses retailing fresh fruits and vegetables, including organic and conventional varieties. This market also includes wholesalers who stock and distribute large quantities of produce to supermarkets, restaurants, food service industries and other retailers.

This market features various segments like chain restaurants, single-location eateries, hotels and food services. Also, it includes other contract-feeding bodies such as schools, healthcare facilities and corporate businesses. Each segment provides diverse food and beverage services catering to a broad customer base.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment accounts for sales of a wide variety of vegetables, either fresh or packaged, such as potatoes, tomatoes, onions, lettuce and broccoli. Frozen vegetables are included in the Other segment.
This segment accounts for sales of various fruits, including, but not limited to, apples, grapes, citrus fruits, pears and many other types. Frozen fruits are included in the Other segment.

This retail segment involves selling products such as fresh meat, seafood, poultry, various dry goods like pasta and rice, a wide range of frozen foods, including fruits and vegetables and various other miscellaneous items.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita fruit and vegetable consumption significantly influences industry operators. Despite rising disposable income levels and several public health campaigns aimed at increasing US fruit and vegetable consumption, increasingly time-crunched consumers continue to opt for fast food, which typically includes more meat and carbohydrates than fruits and vegetables. A drop in per capita fruit and vegetable consumption poses a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The moderate climate and fertile soil in the Mid-Atlantic create ideal conditions for cultivating a variety of fruits and vegetables.
The Northeast's proximity to major cities like New York, Philadelphia, and Washington D.C. provides an extensive and consistent customer base for fresh produce markets.

The Southeast region has the highest population overall in the country, which provides businesses with a large customer base. The Southeast's warmer, milder climate allows for longer growing seasons than other regions.

California's high population, low precipitation rate, significant cities and high median household income make it desirable for companies. According to the California Department of Food and Agriculture (CDFA), the state produces more than a third of the vegetables and almost three-quarters of the fruits in the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Operators in the Fruit and Vegetable Markets industry must adhere to various governmental regulations and policies. Before selling products, each establishment must obtain permits from a local government. Also, food distributors have to comply with a range of regulations, most notably the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, which regulates the receipt, storage and sale of food.

Meat, poultry, fish and dairy must also follow additional sanitation requirements. Farmers' market vendors face different rules than standard vendors. They often don't require permits and lenient packaging and labeling rules. However, markets must be certified by the Agricultural Commissioner and operated by certified producers or approved entities.

Under the National Organic Program, producers and handlers that sell organic products must be certified by a US Department of Agriculture-accredited certifying agent to sell, label or represent their products as organic.
Some industry establishments must also comply with the Bioterrorism Act of 2002. Under the Act, establishments packing or holding food for consumption must register with federal authorities.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.
The capital intensity level is low.
The technology change level is low.
The globalization level is low and steady.
New businesses entering the fruit and vegetable market must absorb the financial burden of adhering to local health and safety rules and regulations and obtaining necessary permits.
Initial required expenditures for a business venture often include costs related to advertising campaigns, warehouse storage, storefront displays, and additional unexpected outlays.
Differentiation could be challenging for new fruit and vegetable retailers, especially if they only offer standard products without unique features or added value.

The labor-intensive nature of farming, combined with seasonal worker shortages, demands efficient management and substantial human resources, posing a significant challenge for newcomers to the industry.

factors_increased_barrier: The industry assistance level is low and steady.
The competition level is high and increasing.
factors_decreased_barrier: The capital intensity level is low.
The technology change level is low.
The globalization level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from supermarkets, grocery stores and convenience stores
basis_points.basis_description: The industry endures competition from supermarkets, grocery stores and convenience stores.
Fruit and vegetable retailers operate on a local basis.

concentration_points.concentration_description: There are a high number of small establishments.
The fruit and vegetable market predominantly comprises numerous small establishments.
Since most establishments only serve local communities, the level of market share concentration is unlikely to change dramatically in the near future.
Farmers' markets, which a local government must operate, often have associations to help vendors boost their efficiency and sales.
Despite efforts to expand vendors' sales, concentration is expected to remain low because no cohesive organization allows businesses to sell their products nationwide.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Have Rose Along With The Prices Of
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like many sectors in the food retailing industries, the fruit and vegetable market in the US sees its most significant expenses from the cost of purchasing goods.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The labor-intensive nature of farming, combined with seasonal worker shortages, demands efficient management and substantial human resources.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The prices of the industry's primary products, such as fruit, vegetables and seafood, have increased.
As many merchants are also farmers themselves, weather conditions have a significant effect on industry revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ELECTRONIC POINT OF SALES SYSTEMS ARE POPULAR AMONG FRUIT AND VEGETABLE MARKETS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: In recent years, some fruit and vegetable retailers have incorporated electronic point-of-sales systems.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demand for fruits and vegetables is tied to healthy eating per capita consumption and per capita disposable income trends.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a wide range of products?
FAQs.answer: Specialized retailers may have a competitive edge in a specific segment, boosting sales volumes.

FAQs.question: Is your company located close to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Retailers located close to key buying markets will exhibit lower purchase costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to revenue volatility?
FAQs.answer: Retailers entering long-term input supply contracts with upstream crop producers will exhibit lower purchase costs.

FAQs.question: How has your company been leveraging the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: By adopting electronic inventory management and point-of-sale systems, retailers can boost the size of their customer base.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Retailers that adopt the latest technologies will exhibit higher operating efficiencies.

FAQs.question: What factors influence the per capita consumption of fruit and vegetables? How can your own branding incorporate these drivers?
FAQs.answer: Despite rising disposable income levels, along with several public health campaigns aimed at increasing US fruit and vegetable consumption, increasingly time-crunched consumers continue to opt for fast food.
